title: Salt-affected soils: discovering a missed reality

tasks.task: Identify and describe the characteristics and impacts of salt-affected soils (seline and sodic) on agricultural productivity.
subtasks: Explain the presence of excessive soluble salts in saline soils and their effect on plant water absorption.
Describe the impact of high sodium ion levels in sodic soils on soil structure, becoming hard and compact when dry and sticky when wet.
Discuss the reduction in agricultural productivity caused by seline and sodic conditions, noting that over 833 million hectares are affected.

tasks.task: Analyze the drivers of salt-affected soils, both natural and human-induced.
subtasks: Mention natural occurrences of seline and sodic soils in arid, semi-arid, and coastal environments.
Provide an example of a natural landscape with silicic and sodic soils, such as the Ayuni salt flat in Bolivia, where quinoa real and camelid vegetation are present.

Identify human-induced factors contributing to salinization and sodification, including unsustainable agricultural practices, irrigation with poor water quality, removal of deep-rooted vegetation, coastal water pumping, and overuse of fertilizers.
Discuss the exacerbating effect of climate change on coastal soils through seawater intrusion.

tasks.task: Propose strategies to manage and mitigate salt-affected soils.
subtasks: Emphasize conservation of natural ecosystems susceptible to salinity and sodicity.
Promote sustainable soil and water management practices.
Suggest adopting appropriate irrigation techniques and suitable crops adapted to saline conditions.
Encourage a harmonious approach to managing salt-affected soils to halt salinization and improve productivity.
